data.title: simple encryption
data.statement:
A computer character is represented in binary using 8 bits. In this context, we are working with 8 bits, and even the insignificant bits are represented. For example, 13 in binary is 00001101.
Encrypt each input integer [[i_input]] separated by a space so that the first bit is swapped with the last bit in the binary representation of these integers. The output is a character string containing the encrypted integers [[i_output]] separated by a space.
For example, 168 in binary is 10111100. After swapping the first bit which is at index [0], here (0) with the last bit at index [7] which is here (1), we will have 00111101, which is 61.
data.inputDescription: <<Line 1 :>> String of characters [[s_input]] containing integers to be encrypted separated by a space.
data.outputDescription: <<Line 1 :>>  Character string [[s_output]]  containing integers to encrypt separated by a space.

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

A computer character is represented in binary using 8 bits. In this context, we are working with 8 bits, and even the insignificant bits are represented. For example, 13 in binary is 00001101.
Encrypt each input integer i_input separated by a space so that the first bit is swapped with the last bit in the binary representation of these integers. The output is a character string containing the encrypted integers i_output separated by a space.
For example, 168 in binary is 10111100. After swapping the first bit which is at index [0], here (0) with the last bit at index [7] which is here (1), we will have 00111101, which is 61.
Input
Line 1 : String of characters s_input containing integers to be encrypted separated by a space.
Output
Line 1 : Character string s_output containing integers to encrypt separated by a space.
Constraints
0 <= s_input ≤ 255
0 <= s_output ≤ 255
0 <= i_input <= 255
0 <= i_output <= 255
Example
Input
140 25 58 64
Output
13 152 58 64
